journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons

title-group.article-title: Optimizing Outpatient Shoulder Surgery: A Review of Anesthetic Options

contrib-group.aff: From the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Corewell Health William Beaumont University Hospital, Royal Oak, MI.

abstract.p: With the recent trends toward outpatient shoulder surgery, standardized protocols for perioperative analgesia are critical for reducing length of stay and optimizing outcomes. There are a variety of described anesthetic and analgesic options for shoulder surgery, and the literature is variable regarding optimal choice as patient, provider, and institutional factors often play a role. With general anesthesia alone becoming less utilized, regional methods require critical examination. Knowledge of the differing, and novel, regional anesthetic procedures in conjunction with recent orthopaedic and anesthetic literature is imperative to providing patients with optimal and efficient care.

body.p: Open shoulder procedures, primarily anatomic and reverse total shoulder arthroplasty (TSA), are being performed at an increasing rate of 7% to 13% each year.1 With the increasing age of the population, expanding indications for these procedures, and drive for healthcare cost savings, there is an expected continued increase in elective and outpatient shoulder surgery of more than 230% by 2025.1,2 Outpatient TSA has been cited to result in an average cost saving of $3,614 to $5,594 per patient with some studies stating the potential to save up to $52,202 per patient in comparison with short-term hospital stays.2,3 There is also increasing pressure to prevent readmissions because the Medicare bundled payment system does not reimburse hospitals for readmissions in the global period.1

Standardized protocols for perioperative analgesia aimed at maximizing pain relief while minimizing narcotic consumption are critical for reducing length of stay and optimizing outcomes.2 Every patient needs individualized care based on medical and surgical history along with anatomic/habitus considerations. A recent cross-sectional study by Furtado et al4 highlighted the importance of preoperative discussion on the elements of expected pain after TSA and the varying options for intraoperative and postoperative pain management. They noted that 87% and 89% of patients find the discussion of the process of anesthesia and expectations for hospital stay and discharge to be of respective importance.

The variety of treatment options to optimize pain management and discharge are broad and often based on surgeon or hospital system preference. The literature is variable regarding optimal choices. The purpose of this review was to examine and detail the options for anesthesia and outpatient perioperative pain management in patients undergoing shoulder procedures while providing a broad overview of recent trends in literature.

sec.title: General Versus Regional Anesthesia
sec.p: Shoulder surgery can be accomplished using general anesthesia (GA), sedation, or with combinations of regional and local anesthetics when awake. It is often the decision of the anesthesiologist on whether a patient is an ideal candidate for general or regional anesthesia (RA) with the positioning of the patient playing a role.5 GA is the most predictable method of achieving adequate airway protection and patient relaxation because the anesthesiologist has the option to safely use paralytics. Other advantages of GA include amnestic properties, analgesia, autonomic/sensory blockades to noxious stimuli, and the secondary ability to markedly aid in glenoid exposure.6,7

However, GA has been historically associated with an increased likelihood of cardiopulmonary complications; prolonged intubation; barotrauma of the lungs; upper airway abrasion/injury; increased intraoperative and postoperative opioid use; longer post-anesthesia care unit stays; intensive care unit transfer; longer hospital stays; and more readmissions for pain, sedation, and nausea/vomiting.3,5,7,8 Cerebral hypoperfusion is another concern, particularly of the contralateral side, when using GA and beach chair positioning. Desaturation and varying neurologic events have been described as high as 25% in this setting.9 In a recent retrospective review of intraoperative hemodynamic responses, Coşarcan et al9 found that the addition of interscalene block (ISB) to GA in those undergoing shoulder arthroscopy can provide protective oxygenation that may minimize these events. Minimizing these potential risks is important when considering same-day surgery.

With the risks detailed above, many surgeons and patients elect for additional or isolated regional methods. RA aims to deliver agents to a particular location of the body with the purpose of dermatomal and/or myotomal effects and can be combined with sedatives or a lessened degree of GA. The different options for RA include continuous or single-shot interscalene brachial plexus blocks (CISBs and SSISBs), supraclavicular nerve blocks (SCNBs), infraclavicular nerve blocks (ICNBs), suprascapular nerve blocks (SSNBs), axillary nerve blocks (ANBs), intra-articular blocks (I-ANBs), and high-thoracic erector spinae fascial plane blocks (HT-ESPBs). However, studies have shown that regional methods are not always 100% effective and conversion to GA can occur.5 Transient and permanent nerve injury, persistent pain, vocal cord paralysis, severe respiratory complications including diaphragmatic paralysis, local adverse reactions, and intravascular injection are known complications.1,7

A recent meta-analysis of 14 studies by Boin et al7 demonstrated sufficient evidence to support RA over GA regarding perioperative opioid consumption, pulmonary complications, hospital length of stay, and GA-related complications in patients undergoing TSA. The combination of GA with RA has also been associated with shorter extubation time, faster recovery, less opioid consumption, lower pain scores, decreased heart rate, decreased systolic blood pressure, overall incidence of adverse events, and readmission rates.5,6 Contrarily, a recent database study by Chen et al1 found that RA in differing combinations of GA has no differences in postoperative complications in those undergoing primary shoulder arthroplasty. The external validity of database studies should be considered when evaluating this literature.

sec.title: Interscalene Blocks
sec.p: Long-duration nerve blocks have been extensively studied and have been shown to decrease opioid use after shoulder surgery.3 Interscalene blocks are designed to provide blockade to most of the brachial plexuses ranging from C5 to T1 and have been recognized as the gold standard for postoperative analgesia after shoulder procedures.10 The coverage goal includes the middle and upper trunks of the brachial plexus that generally spares the ulnar nerve distribution.6,11 The nerve roots of the brachial plexus pass anterior to the middle scalene although anatomic variants have been described (Figure 1). The typical ISB is composed of a small volume of a long-acting anesthetic such as bupivacaine or ropivacaine with the goal of lasting at least 24 hours.6,12

caption.p: Image demonstrating ISB location from anterior view (purple X's). Coverage includes C5-T1 but often spares ulnar nerve distributions (C8-T1).

sec.p: ISBs are performed either preoperatively or postoperatively with careful attention to avoid vital structures such as the subclavian vein and artery. The procedure is typically performed by ultrasonography guidance. Contraindications to ISB include active cellulitis or infectious process, known allergies to medications used, severe pulmonary conditions, disorders affecting normal anatomy, peripheral nerve conditions affecting the ipsilateral upper extremity such as previous brachial plexus injuries, and phrenic nerve palsy/diaphragm paralysis of the contralateral side.13 The human response to ISB anesthesia has been studied in a recent quantitative analysis by Sato et al14 in which they recorded nerve response indices in patients undergoing ISB versus non-ISB. They concluded that the nociceptive nerve responses were markedly less in patients undergoing TSA with ISB.

The two main methods of interscalene blockade include single-shot injection and continuous (C) catheter release. The proposed benefits of SSISB are improved analgesia, less nausea, lower risk of neurologic injury, lower risk of diaphragmatic injury, avoidance of catheter-associated complications, and overall improved satisfaction.3 However, main concerns of SSISB include a shorter duration and the “rebound effect” of perceived pain increase after the blocks wear off.15 The proposed benefits of CISB include prolonged analgesia, decreased opioid requirements, and shorter length of stay although recent studies indicate that increased risks of complications and barriers to discharge may be higher with CISB.6,8,16

Although generally considered safe, there are a variety of documented complications that can occur with either form of ISB with some being very serious. Nerve injury has been estimated to occur between 0.6% and 8%, with most being temporary.12 Aberrant needle or anesthetic placement has been known to result in pneumothorax, transient or permanent ipsilateral hemiparesis of the diaphragm, hoarseness, vocal cord paralysis, Horner syndrome, hematoma, intravascular injection, nerve damage, local toxicity, infection, epidural/subarachnoid placement, and allergic reactions.12,17 Xu et al17 found a 34% overall respiratory complication rate in patients undergoing ISB, with 27% of those being considered mild. They concluded that preoperative cardiopulmonary status and obesity were associated with an increased risk of CISB respiratory complications.

Another concern of ISB is the masking effect it may have on postoperative detection of iatrogenic nerve injuries, particularly if the block is done preoperatively. A retrospective study from Kim et al18 found that postoperative administration of CISB is a safe and effective method for providing postoperative analgesia and affording the opportunity to detect a postoperative nerve injury. This method should be considered generally safe and effective, but prospective randomized trials are lacking.

CISB versus SSISB remains debatable as each method has risks and benefits. There are data to support lower pain scores and perioperative opioid requirements with CISB; however, the logistical issues and potential respiratory complications and dislodgement remain a major concern.7 A perineural catheter requires protocols and aptitude to assist patients and caregivers with proper management, and the generalizability of its use is often not straightforward.3,19 In a recent systematic review, Allahabadi et al20 suggested a higher rate of re-presentation after discharge in patients with indwelling catheters, with the primary causes being persistent pain and/or dislodgement of the catheter. They demonstrated a relatively low overall complication rate with CISB but emphasized the importance of a proper system to manage issues that may arise. Teske et al19 found in their retrospective study up to five times higher complication rates and ED visits with continuous blocks, with the majority being pulmonary-related issues. A prospective randomized controlled trial by Rhyner et al16 investigated 60 patients undergoing major shoulder surgery and found that CISB did not provide superior analgesia compared with SSISB with supplementary multimodal analgesia. In another prospective randomized trial by Krupp et al,21 SSISB was shown to provide a decreased narcotic consumption relationship in the first 24 to 48 hours, less time for administration, and less healthcare system costs ($190.17 versus $357.12) compared with CISB. Levin et al15 found lower pain scores, lower incidence of severe pain, and lower rates of postoperative opioid regimens in their retrospective study of patients undergoing SSISB versus CISB. Although there is not a clear reasoning as to the mechanism of why SSISBs have potential for decreased narcotic consumption, the potential benefits of CISB must be carefully weighed with the potential risks.

Superior trunk blockade (STB) is a relatively novel method of ISB intended to isolate the superior portion of the plexus with the goal of reducing phrenic nerve involvement.13 This procedure is performed in a similar anatomic location as described for ISBs (Figure 1). The indications and contraindications are similar to the more standard forms of ISB. A unique complication of this technique is injury to the dorsal scapular nerve.13 A recent randomized trial by Zhang et al22 demonstrated that STB provided noninferior analgesia in the immediate postoperative state with less occurrences of hemidiaphragmatic paresis in comparison with SSISB. However, Lee et al23 demonstrated that STB did not reduce the rates of hemidiaphragm paralysis and provided inferior quality of surgical anesthesia in their randomized trial.

sec.title: Supraclavicular and Infraclavicular Blocks
sec.p: Supraclavicular and infraclavicular blocks are two other techniques to deliver RA. The aim of these blocks is the trunk/proximal divisional level of the brachial plexus, given the more lateral location of the procedure (Figure 2). The coverage area typically spans the distal two-thirds of the upper extremity and proximal shoulder nerve distributions; however, there is concern of incomplete shoulder coverage secondary to shoulder contributions of the suprascapular nerve.6 Complications and contraindications of SCNB and ICNB are otherwise similar to ISBs. Historically, SCNBs were associated with higher incidences of pneumothorax compared with ISB before the advent of ultrasonography guidance.6 A recent meta-analysis by Schubert et al24 demonstrated that SCNBs, in comparison with ISBs, had clinically comparable postoperative pain scores, opioid usage, reduced incidence of hoarseness, hemidiaphragm paresis, and Horner syndrome in varying arthroscopic and open shoulder procedures.

caption.p: Image demonstrating supraclavicular (black X) and infraclavicular (purple X) block location from anterior view. Coverage includes distal two-thirds of the upper extremity and proximal shoulder but often spares suprascapular nerve contributions.

sec.p: ICNB techniques (including costoclavicular approaches) were, therefore, developed to avoid SCNB-related complications but have been largely avoided because of cautionary anatomic/habitus considerations of major structures and lack of comfort with the technique.5,6,25 The deep anatomy and stabilizing pectoral musculature make ICNB an attractive option. There are limited high-quality studies comparing the efficacy of ICNB with ISB. However, this remains an option in patients with more pressing contraindications for ISB. A recent prospective, randomized trial by Saxena et al25 found that ICNB can be an effective method of pain management for shoulder surgery, particularly when combined with suprascapular nerve blockade.

sec.title: Suprascapular and Axillary Blocks
sec.p: SSNB and ANB in isolation or combination are other novel options for analgesia during shoulder surgery.26 The suprascapular nerve innervates roughly 70% of the deep shoulder girdle, with the remaining 30% being covered by the axillary, subscapular, musculocutaneous, and lateral pectoral nerves.6 These blocks are, therefore, typically performed by two separate injections including a posterior approach in the sitting position with the scapula protracted (Figures 3 and 4). Ultrasonography is again typically used.26 The proposed main advantage of this method is avoidance of complications associated with proximal structures about the plexus including the phrenic nerve as discussed with the previous methods.

caption.p: Image demonstrating axillary nerve block location from posterior view (purple X). Coverage includes C5-C6 contributions (30% of shoulder joint).
Image demonstrating suprascapular nerve block location from superior view (purple X). Coverage includes C5-C6 distribution (70% of the shoulder joint).

sec.p: This technique was noninferior to ISB with decreased incidence of diaphragmatic complications in patients undergoing shoulder arthroscopy with limited studies examining open shoulder procedures.3 A recent meta-analysis by White et al27 demonstrated SSNBs to have a lower incidence of Horner syndrome, hoarseness, and clinically impaired pulmonary function. However, ISBs in comparison were noted to have statistically significant reductions in pain scores.

sec.title: High-Thoracic Erector Spinae Fascial Plane Blocks
sec.p: High-thoracic erector spinae fascial plane (HT-ESP) blockade is another novel option with limited data to support or refute as an effective anesthetic. This technique was first described in 2016 and has been primarily used for acute and chronic pain conditions of the thorax, spine, upper limbs, and lower limbs28 (Figure 5). The use of HT-ESPB has been proposed as a safe, easy, phrenic nerve-sparing alternative to ISB with the mechanism of electrical neuromodulation on perineural and/or central nerve inhibition.28 Shanthanna et al29 recently conducted a randomized controlled trial and found no difference in pain scores in comparing placebo with HT-ESPB. A randomized prospective trial by Kapukaya et al10 compared this technique with ISB in 60 patients. They found that pain scores and postoperative narcotic/rescue analgesics were higher in the HT-ESPB group, concluding that ISB may be more effective in shoulder arthroscopy. A randomized trial by Sun et al30 suggested that HT-ESBP can be an effective phrenic-sparing option; however, CISB offered superior opioid-sparing effects in the immediate postoperative period. Their study was limited by a small sample size of 16.

caption.p: Image demonstrating HTESB location from posterior view (purple X's). Coverage includes dorsal and ventral rami of thoracic and abdominal spinal nerves.

sec.title: Adjuvants
sec.p: There are a variety of options for adjuvant anesthetic/analgesic administration because the duration of the aforementioned methods are unpredictable.3,5 Adjuvants act to prolong the effects of the anesthetic agents with the theory that this may reduce postoperative opioid consumption and reduce rebound phenomenon.31 Adjuvants should not be considered benign because they each carry side effects, contraindications, and potential to do more harm than good. This review will focus on some of the more commonly used adjuvants (Table 1).

Periarticular infiltration (PAI) with local anesthetic has been advocated as an adjunct for pain control with particular attention to liposomal formulations.32 The method of delivery includes manual injection in several safe soft-tissue regions about the shoulder joint complex (ie, joint capsule, cuff musculature, and superficial musculature). Local anesthesia is considered to be generally safe and less likely to be associated with rebound pain in comparison with ISB.12,33 Contraindications lie in the medical feasibility of safe metabolism from a systemic standpoint.

A recent meta-analysis by Boin et al7 did not provide evidence to show additional benefits of local anesthesia in comparison with SSISB or CISB alone. Schumaier et al12 compared PAI with ISB in patients undergoing TSA in a recent prospective randomized trial. They found that patients had higher satisfaction in the ISB group and no clinical differences in pain-related postoperative reports, visual analong scale (VAS) scores, length of stay, and overall narcotic consumption. This is consistent in other studies.29,33

Sahin et al34 demonstrated PAI to be a viable alternative in comparison with combined SSNB and ANB in patients undergoing shoulder arthroscopy in their recent randomized trial. They found markedly lower pain scores and opioid requirements in patients with PAI blockade in the first 24 hours after surgery. The addition of a periarticular injection also has some evidence to support in combination with ISB. Vijittrakarnrung et al32 recently conducted a retrospective cohort study and found that the combination of ISB with PAI had markedly less total opioid consumption and lower pain scores at 24 hours in comparison with ISB alone.

Liposomal formulations and encapsulated delivery methods of local anesthetics are at the forefront of recent investigation (Table 2). Liposomal bupivacaine (LB) was approved by the FDA in 2011 as a formulation with the purpose of prolonged administration of up to 72 hours for the use in ISB and can be administered by block or local tissue infiltration.31,33 It has been shown in previous literature to decrease pain, increase satisfaction, and decrease overall opioid consumption when used in concert with ISB and has been associated with lower costs and complication rates when compared with CISB.6,15 LB was found to be comparable with nonliposomal preparations in its opioid-sparing effects, pain relief, adverse reactions, length of stay, and complication rates in the first 48 hours after TSA in recent meta-analyses by Boin et al7 and by Li et al.35

caption.p: Summary of Reviewed Articles Comparing LB in Varying Designs

fn.p: CISB = continuous interscalene brachial plexus block, LB = liposomal bupivacaine, SSISB = single-shot interscalene brachial plexus block, TSA = total shoulder arthroplasty

sec.p: Prospective randomized trials have offered differing conclusions. Namdari et al33 concluded that local LB suspensions were associated with greater intraoperative narcotic consumption and equivalent postoperative narcotic usage in comparison with those treated with ISB alone. Similar findings of increased intraoperative consumption, worse pain in the immediate postoperative period, and decreased patient satisfaction have been shown in other recent prospective trials.12,31,36 Ewing et al36 estimated the cost difference between LB and joint cocktail local infiltration to be $1718 versus $157, which is another important consideration.

Dexamethasone is another studied adjuvant without clear adjunctive analgesic mechanism. The addition of preservative-free perineural and intravenous (IV) dexamethasone has been shown to prolong the duration of nerve blocks, reduce nausea, reduce rebound pain and VAS scores, prolong time until peak pain, decrease postoperative nausea/vomiting, and reduce sleep disturbances in patients undergoing ambulatory TSA and rotator cuff repair. It is a generally supported adjuvant for both ISBs and STBs.3,7

Gabapentinoids are a class of medications that act on peripheral nerve receptors with the effect of inhibiting ascending pain transmission and preventing hyperalgesia. There are limited high-quality studies on this adjuvant, and the efficacy and safety are debated because this class of medication is not FDA-approved for treating or preventing surgical pain.37 However, there are studies that have concluded that its role in a postoperative multimodal pain regimen has potential to be safe and reduce the use of narcotics after orthopaedic surgery.37,38 Its benefit must be carefully weighed with the risk profile to induce harm, particularly in older patients and those on other neuromodulating medications.37

Tramadol is another adjuvant that works in a differing manner to the others mentioned and does not fit the standard mechanism of opioids, making it an alternative option. A recent retrospective cohort study conducted by Kopriva et al39 suggested that preoperative tramadol can produce an environment for a lesser postoperative risk profile. However, the potential for opioid-like side effects, in conjunction with seizures and serotonergic reactions, must not be ignored. Its safety profile and literature support must be carefully considered when using this medication at any time point in patients undergoing shoulder arthroplasty.

Cryoneurolysis is another novel method of adjuvant pain management in patients undergoing shoulder arthroplasty. Cryoneurolysis is the process of applying extremely cold temperatures to targeted nerve tissue to reversibly disrupt pain signal conduction from the peripheral source using ultrasonography guidance.40 This is typically achieved by suprascapular nerve targeting and has not been shown to affect motor function of the nerve in case reports.40 The low risk profile without motor blockade is why this method is attractive, but additional studies are needed to support or refute its efficacy and feasibility in routine practice.

Regardless of primary anesthetic choice, multimodal analgesia is a critical component to the pathway toward outpatient shoulder procedures.3 In a prospective randomized trial study by Jolissaint et al,38 they found that a multimodal opioid-free perioperative pain management pathway is effective and safe in patients undergoing TSA. The ideal multimodal regimen is ultimately an individualized decision based on a multitude of factors and systems at play. Involvement with anesthesia and primary care colleagues is of utmost importance when making these decisions at all stages of the perioperative period.

sec.title: Authors’ Preferred Method
sec.p: Preferred methods vary slightly between the authors, given previous experiences and variability in surgical site locations and anesthesiologist comfort/preference. We prefer CISB if certain criteria are met (no pulmonary disease or nerve deficits, experienced and willing anesthesiologist, postoperative management of any catheter or pump related complications by anesthesia providers, and patient willing/able to comply with catheter management). SSISB with LB is utilized if no contraindications otherwise. Postoperatively, a multimodal oral regimen including acetaminophen every 6 hours, tramadol every 6 hours as needed, a limited prescription for oxycodone every 6 hours as needed, once nightly gabapentin for 5 days, 30 days of once daily meloxicam, and a one-time dose of dexamethasone the morning after surgery is prescribed (Table 3). A cold therapy machine is recommended with direction to avoid direct skin contact. Detailed instructions and resources on CISB management are given to patients for education and to mitigate potential calls/visits for complications related to catheters.

caption.p: Authors’ Proposed Model for Ambulatory Multimodal Analgesia after TSA with Modifications of Pathway from Dong et al3

tr.td: Discuss expectationsEducate patient and caregiversReview primary provider and specialist recommendations
Chart review, succinct and straightforward patient discussion, attempt to wean from current opioids if possible
Provide adequate analgesia during first 2-5 postoperative d
CISB or SSISB (surgeon and institution dependent), LB based on delivery method
Avoidance of additional pain generatorsMultimodal approach
Proper padded positioning (pain)Minimize opioids (pain)Ketamine 20-50 mg IV (pain)Dexamethasone 4 mg IV (nausea)Ondansetron 4 mg IV (nausea)

Cold therapy machine (avoid direct skin contact)Acetaminophen 1,000 mg oral scheduled every 6 hr (central, mild pain)Tramadol 50 mg oral as needed every 6 hr (alternate with opioids) (moderate pain)Meloxicam 15 mg once daily for 30 d (anti-inflammatory, pain)Gabapentin 100 mg every night for 5 d (nerve-related pain)Oxycodone 5 mg as needed every 6 hr (alternate with tramadol) (pain)Dexamethasone 6 mg oral one dose on morning after surgery (nausea and pain adjunct)

fn.p: CISB = continuous interscalene brachial plexus block, LB = liposomal bupivacaine, SSISB = single-shot interscalene brachial plexus block, TSA = total shoulder arthroplasty

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Optimizing pain management after shoulder surgery is important, particularly considering recent trends and motivations toward outpatient shoulder procedures. All options carry a risk/benefit profile, and each patient must receive individualized decisions in conjunction with anesthesia and primary teams with the goal of providing patients with the best possible outcome.
